instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the analysis of protein content in instant coffee?
Output: The analysis of protein content in instant coffee using NIR spectroscopy utilized near-infrared (NIR) spectrum.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the analysis of protein content in instant coffee?
Output: The specific spectral feature processing methods used in the modeling analysis of protein content in instant coffee was baseline correction.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the models in the analysis of protein content in instant coffee using, and how accurate were the results?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the models in the analysis of protein content in instant coffee using NIR spectroscopy was the root mean square error (RMSE). The optimal LV-SVM model had a validating RMSE of 6.797 and a testing RMSE of 8.384. The optimal LV-ELM model had a validating RMSE of 6.118 and a testing RMSE of 7.837. These results indicate the accuracy of the models in predicting the protein content in instant coffee using NIR spectroscopy.

instruction: What was the purpose of using support vector machine (SVM) and extreme learning machine (ELM) in the modeling analysis of protein content in instant coffee using NIR spectroscopy?
Output: The purpose of using support vector machine (SVM) and extreme learning machine (ELM) in the modeling analysis of protein content in instant coffee using NIR spectroscopy was to validate their practicality and evaluate their performance in predicting protein content. These machine learning methods, combined with latent variable analysis technique, were used to develop analytical models based on the NIR data. The tuning of latent variables and optimization of key parameters in the machines were done jointly, allowing for data dimension reduction and selection of machine parameters in a single modeling process. The models were trained using a calibrating sample set and then validated and tested using separate sample sets. The performance of the SVM and ELM models was compared to the common partial least square method, and it was found that the SVM and ELM methods provided better prediction results. This demonstrated the application advantages of the latent variable machine learning methods in near-infrared quantitative analysis and suggested their potential for content detection in other types of coffee.

instruction: Can the support vector machine (SVM) and extreme learning machine (ELM) methods be considered superior to the common partial least square method in the analysis of protein content in instant coffee using near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy?
Output: Yes, the support vector machine (SVM) and extreme learning machine (ELM) methods can be considered superior to the common partial least square method in the analysis of protein content in instant coffee using near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy. This is supported by the text, which states that the LV-SVM and LV-ELM methods have better prediction results compared to the common partial least square method. The optimal LV-SVM model had a validating root mean square error of 6.797 and a testing root mean square error of 8.384, while the optimal LV-ELM model had a validating root mean square error of 6.118 and a testing root mean square error of 7.837. These results verify the application advantages of the latent variable machine learning methods in near-infrared quantitative analysis.
